tgt_text.0: A MEAGRE array of facts more or less controverted, and a few critical remarks, are all we can offer towards a biography of Valerius Catullus.
tgt_text.1: We learn from the testimony of many ancient writers, that he was a na­ tive of Verona or its immediate neighbourhood;
tgt_text.2: and the Marquis Scipiu Maffei, himself a Veronese, asserts that in his day there were still traits of the language of Catullus in the dialect of his countrymen.
tgt_text.3: Whether the poet's prænomen was Caius or Quintus is uncertain, the former being assigned to him by Apuleius, the latter by Pliny.
tgt_text.4: A more important ques­ tion is that which concerns the dates of his birth and death.
tgt_text.5: According to Hieronymus, in the Eusebian chronicle, he was born B. c. 87, and died in his thirtieth year, B. C. 57.
tgt_text.6: The second date is undoubtedly erroneous, for we have positive evidence from his own works that he was alive in the consulship of Vatinius, B. c. 47.
tgt_text.7: It is evident too that he must have sur­ vived at least till B. c. 45, for Cicero, in his Letters, talks of the verses of Catullus against Cæsar and Mamurra (xxix.) as newly written, and first seen by Cæsar in that year.
tgt_text.8: The chronologer's mistake as to the time of the poet's death, throws some doubt also on that which he assigns to his birth.
tgt_text.9: We shall however be exact enough for all literary purposes, if we conclude with Dunlop that Catullus " was nearly contemporary with Lucretius, having come into the world a few years after him, and having survived him but a short period.
tgt_text.10: "It is not certain that the poet belonged to the patrician family of the Valerii, but his father must have been a person of some consideration, for he was the friend and habitual entertainer of Julius Cæsar.
tgt_text.11: The son took up his abode in Rome in the very spring of youth (LXVIII. 15) and plunged without restraint into all the expensive pleasures of the best-that is to say, the most debauched-society.
tgt_text.12: This is sufficient to account for the jocular complaints of poverty interspersed through his writings.
tgt_text.13: It is easy to conceive that one whose only business was to enjoy life in an age and in a city of unbounded luxury, and who was a liberal purchaser of such commodities as were dealt in by the worthy Silo (ciii.), should have been often " hard up''. for cash;
tgt_text.14: and that he should have had occasion for frequent intercourse with lawyers and orators, such as Alphenus Varus Licinius Calvus, and M. Tullius Cicero.
tgt_text.15: Yet his fortune was by no means small, for he possessed a noble villa on the beautiful promontory of Sir­ mio, another near Tibur, and he made a voyage from the Pontus in his own yacht.
tgt_text.16: To improve his pecuniary circumstances, he adopted the usual Roman expedient for quickly filling a lank purse, and accompanied Caius Memmius, the celebrated patron of Lucretius, to Bithynia, when he was appointed Prætor of that province.
tgt_text.17: But it is plain from his direct testimony, as well as from the bitterness of his invectives against his chief, that he derived little profit from that expedition.
tgt_text.18: Catullus repeatedly deplores with every mark of heartfelt grief the loss of a brother who died in the Troad.
tgt_text.19: This event is generally supposed to have happened whilst the poet was in Bithynia;
tgt_text.20: but, as Professor Ramsay has well remarked, " any evidence we possess leads to a different conclu­ sion.
tgt_text.21: When railing against the evil fortune which attended the journey to the East, he makes no allusion to any such misfortune as this;
tgt_text.22: we find no notice of the event in the pieces written immediately before quit­ ting Asia and immediately after his return to Italy;
tgt_text.23: nor does the language of those passages in which he gives vent to his sorrow, in any way con­ firm the conjecture.
tgt_text.24: "Gifted with a fine person, a vigorous constitution, and rare genius, Ca­ tullus was meant by nature for better things:
tgt_text.25: it was the curse of his times that made him an idler and a voluptuary :
tgt_text.26: O blame not the bard if he fly to the bowers
tgt_text.27: Where Pleasure sits carelessly smiling at Fame ;
tgt_text.28: He was born for much more, and in happier hours
tgt_text.29: His soul might have glowed with a holier flame.
tgt_text.30: That he was not indifferent to public wrongs is proved by the vehe­ mence with which he assailed Cæsar in the plenitude of his power.
tgt_text.31: A man of fine sensibility and delicate fancy, he was no less remarkable for the strength and depth of his feelings.
tgt_text.32: Regarded as indications of character, his poems to Lesbia are unique in Roman literature for the intensity and self-oblivion of the passion they portray.
tgt_text.33: Some of theIr breathe the delicious frenzy of desire;
tgt_text.34: or the sweet sadness that evei mingles with the best of joy, and is so like it that we scarce know whether to call it pain or pleasure ;
tgt_text.35: the rest are heavy with the grief for which there is no cure, the anguish of a heart that dotes, yet more than doubts;
tgt_text.36: that cannot cease to love what it loathes and scorns.
tgt_text.37: Clodia, as we learn from Apuleius, was the real name of Lesbia, " but this bare fact"—we again quote Ramsay—"by no means entitles us to jump to the conclusion at which many have arrived, that she was the sister of the celebrated Clodius slain by Milo.
tgt_text.38: Indeed the presumption is strong against such an inference.
tgt_text.39: The tribute of high-flown praise paid to Cicero would have been but a bad recommendation to the favour of one whom the orator makes the subject of scurrilous jests, and who is said to have cherished against him all the vindictive animosity of a woman first slighted, and then openly insulted."
tgt_text.40: Of other women with whom he may have amused himself, Catullus names only Hypsithilla and Aufi­ lina, ladies of Verona;
tgt_text.41: but the language in which he writes of them de­ notes an intercourse in which the senses were vividly interested, the affec­ tions not at all.
tgt_text.42: Some of his poems are hideous from the traces of a turpitude to which we cannot without a painful effort make even a passing allusion.
tgt_text.43: But so are portions of almost every Roman poet;
tgt_text.44: and amidst our natural disgust at these abominations, and at the filthy ribaldry of many of the short pieces of Catullus, it is right to remember that these things were the vices of the age rather than of the individual. "
tgt_text.45: The filth of Catullus seldom springs from a prurient imagination revelling in voluptuous images ;
tgt_text.46: it rather proceeds from habitual impurity of expres­ sion, and probably gives a fair representation of the manners and con­ versation of the gay society of Rome at that period.
tgt_text.47: "In the contents of a very small book, Catullus has given proof of ex­ traordinary versatility, and consummate skill in the most dissimilar moods of his art.
tgt_text.48: His compass is a wide one, and he is master of all within it.
tgt_text.49: His peculiar characteristics are neatness, racy simplicity graceful turns of thought, and exquisite happiness of expression.
tgt_text.50: In these qualities he has never been surpassed;
tgt_text.51: andthey are apparent alike in his most playful trifles, and when he ascends to the mountain­ heights of passion and imagination.
tgt_text.52: Of him it may be affirmed with ab­ solute truth, that he adorned all he touched ;
tgt_text.53: hence the appropriateness of the epithet doctus which was bestowed upon him by his poetic brethren, not, as many have supposed, because of his proficiency in Greek liter­ ature, but because of his mastery in the art he professed.
tgt_text.54: Doctus does not always mean book-learned ;
tgt_text.55: it is often used to signify skill in any art -as in that of archery for instance, when Tibullus calls Cupid's hands doctas, after they had learned the use of the bow.
tgt_text.56: Doctus means " taught," and as one who is well taught is accomplished in his speciality, the epithet came naturally to bear that secondary signification.
tgt_text.57: That the English epithet "learned" is restricted to one particular kind of proficiency, is merely the result of arbitrary custom.
tgt_text.58: The wider import of the Latin word is better expressed in such obsolete phrases as " cunning of fence," " cunning in music, in mathematics," &c.
tgt_text.59: In this sense Horace applies it to the great actor Roscius;
tgt_text.60: and in this sense it was applied by courtesy to poets in general, and distinctively and emphatically to Catullus.
tgt_text.61: Horace unjustly assumes to himself (Epist. 19, lib. i.) the credit of having been the first to enrich the literature of his country with imi­ tations of the Greek lyric poets;
tgt_text.62: Catullus had preceded him in that field, and with the more essential advantage which genius possesses over talent.
tgt_text.63: " Catullus," says Dunlop. " translated many of the shorter and more delicate pieces of the Greeks;
tgt_text.64: an attempt which hitherto had been thought impossible, though the broad humour of their comedies, the vehement pathos of their tragedies, and the romantic interest of the Odyssey, had stood the transformation.
tgt_text.65: His stay in Bithynia, though little advantageous to his fortune, rendered him better acquainted than he might otherwise have been with the productions of Greece ;
tgt_text.66: and he was therefore in a great degree indebted to this expedition (on which he always appears to have looked back with mortification and disappointment) for those felici­ tous turns of expression, that grace, simplicity, and purity, which are the characteristics of his poems, and of which hitherto Greece alone had af­ forded models.
tgt_text.67: Indeed in all his verses, whether elegiac or heroic, we perceive his imitation of the Greeks, and it must be admitted that he has drawn from them his choicest stores.
tgt_text.69: his Images, similes, metaphors, and addresses to himself, are all Greek ;
tgt_text.70: and even in the versification of his odes we see visible traces of their origin.
tgt_text.71: Nevertheless he was the inventor of a new species of Latin poetry ;
tgt_text.72: and as he was the first who used such variety of measures, and perhaps in­ vented some that were new, he was amply entitled to call the poetical volume which he presented to Cornelius Nepos Lepidum Novum Libellum.
tgt_text.73: The beautiful expressions, too, and idioms of the Greek language, which he has so carefully selected, are woven with such art into the texture of his composition, and so aptly figure the impassioned ideas of his amorous muse, that they have all the fresh and untarnished hues of originality."
tgt_text.74: It is certain that some, and probable that many, of the poems of Catul­ lus have perished.
tgt_text.75: Pliny makes mention of verses upon love-charms of which no trace remains, and Terentianus Maurus mentions some Ithy­ phallica.
tgt_text.76: The scholiasts Servius and Nonius refer to passages which are not to be found in the existing collection of the works of Catullus.
tgt_text.77: On the other hand, the Ciris and the Pervigilium Veneris have been errone­ ously ascribed to him.
tgt_text.78: We should have lost him wholly but for the for­ tuitous discovery of a single manuscript in bad condition, which was found in France in the year 1425.
tgt_text.79: From this source were derived all the MSS.
tgt_text.80: on which the old editions were founded, and hence, as might be expected, the text is very corrupt, and presents a greater number of various and contradictory readings than that of almost any other classic.
tgt_text.81: It is cer­ tain too that it has been repeatedly interpolated.
tgt_text.82: The present prose translation of Catullus, the first, we believe, that has appeared in English, has been framed upon the principle of adhering as closely to the letter of the original as is consistent with the genius of the respective languages.
tgt_text.83: For a faithful rendering of the letter, prose is the best medium;
tgt_text.85: for all beyond we must have recourse to verse.
tgt_text.86: The poetical versions that follow have been carefully selected from many writers, and comprise all the best specimens of their kind that have yet been published.
tgt_text.87: ALBIUS TIBULLUS (his prænomen is unknown) was a Roman knight, contemporary with Horace and Virgil.
tgt_text.88: The date of his birth is uncertain, but must be placed somewhere about B. C. 59, the year in which Livy came into the world.
tgt_text.89: A spurious distich in the fifth Elegy of book iii. was long accepted as proof that Tibullus was born in the same year as Ovid, who, on the contrary, invariably speaks of him as a more ancient writer and an older man than himself, and particularly in a passage of the Tristia, (IV. x.,) in which he fixes the order of succession of the Elegiac poets :
tgt_text.91: and greedy fate Denied Tibullus' friendship, wish'd too late :
tgt_text.92: He followed Gallus, next Propertius came ;
tgt_text.93: The last was I, the fourth successive name.
tgt_text.95: It appears from an epigram of Domitius Marsus, another contempt rary of Tibullus, that he died soon after Virgil, that is to say, in or about B. a 19, while he was yet in the prime of life, or, as the epigram says, while lv was still juvenis, for by that term the Romans meant one who had no­ passed his forty-sixth year.
tgt_text.96: Te quoque, Virgilio comitem, non æqua, Tibulle, Mors juvenem campos misit ad Elysios :
tgt_text.97: Ne foret, aut elegis molles qui fleret amores, Aut caneret forti regia bella pede.
tgt_text.98: Thee, young Tibullus, to th' Elysian plain Death bade accompany great Maro's shade ;
tgt_text.99: Determined that no poet should remain, Or to sing wars, or weep the cruel maid.
tgt_text.101: Tibullus was descended from an ancient and wealthy equestrian family;
tgt_text.102: but we learn from himself that he possessed only a small portion of the estates of his forefathers.
tgt_text.103: The cause of this decline of fortune has been warmly debated among the learned ;
tgt_text.104: some alleging, rightly, as it seems to us, that we need not look further for it than to the confiscations of the tri­ umviri, in which so many Italian estates were involved;
tgt_text.105: others, that he was ruined by his own extravagance.
tgt_text.106: The father of Tibullus had been en­ gaged on the side of Pompey in the civil wars, and died soon after Cæsar had finally triumphed over the liberties of Rome.
tgt_text.107: It is not to be doubted that the patrimony of the son should have been involved in the subsequent partition of the lands of Italy ;
tgt_text.108: and though he saved something from the wreck, probably through the interest of his patron, Messala, we do not find in his Elegies a single expression of gratitude or compliment from which it might be conjectured that Augustus had atoned to him for the wrongs done by Octavius.
tgt_text.109: It is certainly remarkable, in reference to this question, and it raises our respect for the man, that the name of Augustus, celebrated with such persevering and fulsome adulation by the other great poets of the day, is nowhere to be found in the writings of Tibullus.
tgt_text.110: The notion that he wasted his large fortune in dissipation is little more than a gratuitous assumption, the only evidence offered in support of it being a poetical hyperbole.
tgt_text.111: In the fourth Elegy of the second book he declares himself ready to sacrifice all that was left of his hereditary possessions to gratify the demands of his covetous mistress :
tgt_text.112: whence some would have us infer, that the man who could deliberately talk thus, in a good hex­ ameter and pentameter distich, must certainly have made ducks and drakes of his property.
tgt_text.113: We rather think that the general tenour of his writings, as well as the direct testimony of his friend Horace, leads to the opposite conclusion.
tgt_text.114: That discreet Epicurean would not have complimented a reckless spendthrift on his knowledge of the art of enjoyment.
tgt_text.115: Tibullus acquired at an early period the friendship of his great patron, Messala, and retained it to the end of his life.
tgt_text.116: He declined that com­ mander's invitation to accompany him in th3 naval war which was des­ tined to close with the decisive battle of Actium, doubtless because he remained stedfast in his attachment to the cause for which his father had Buffered.
tgt_text.117: Immediately after that victory, Messala was detached by Cæsar to suppress a formidable insurrection which had broker, out in Aquitaine ;
tgt_text.118: and Tibullus accompanied him in the honourable post of contubernalis corresponding nearly to that of aid-de-camp.
tgt_text.119: Part of the glory of the Aquitanian campaign, for which Messala, four years later, obtained a tri­ umph, and which Tibullus celebrates in language of unwonted loftiness, redounds, according to the poet, to his own fame (book I. vii. 9—11).
tgt_text.120: In the following year, (B. c. 30,) Messala was sent to Asia, and again Tibullus went with him, but was taken ill and obliged to remain in Cor­ cyra, an incident which forms the theme of another beautiful poem (book I. iii.).
tgt_text.121: After his recovery he seems to have returned home, and to have spent the rest of his days, excepting occasional visits to the capital, at his coun­ try seat near Pedum, a small town of Latium on the skirts of the Apen­ nines, between Præmeste and Tibur.
tgt_text.122: That he lived there in the enjoy­ ment of a liberal competence is clear enough, and also that when he speaks of his poverty, that term is only to be understood by contrast with the overgrown fortunes of many of his noble countrymen.
tgt_text.123: This is apparent from many of his own expressions (e. g. book I. i. 5) ;
tgt_text.124: as a Roman knight he must have been worth upwards of three thousand pounds;
tgt_text.125: and Horace even speaks of him as wealthy.
tgt_text.126: According to him, Tibullus possessed all the blessings of life :
tgt_text.127: he was beautiful in person (Horace on this point confirms the strong language of the old biographers);
tgt_text.128: he had a competent fortune, favour with the great, fame, health ;
tgt_text.129: and knew how to enjoy all those blessings.

tgt_text.133: Say, dost thou verses write that shall outvie Cassius of Parma's darling poesy ?

tgt_text.147: Notwithstanding all his personal and mental graces, and his singularly Amiable disposition, Tibullus was not happy in love.

tgt_text.158: His last love was the mercen­ ary Nemesis, tv whom the second book and the last two years of the poet's life were devoted, apparently without any return.
tgt_text.159: The third book -if this indeed is the composition of Tibullus—is chiefly occupied with his unfortunate passion for Neæra.
tgt_text.160: Her, it would appear, he wished to marry, he had indeed been actually betrothed to her, but she forsook him on the eve of the nuptials.
tgt_text.161: Lastly, there was Glycera, who gave him great pain by forsaking him for a younger man, and whom wc have no reason for confounding with any of the other three, though she is not known to us from his own writings, but only from the Ode in which Horace attempts to console him for her inconstancy.
tgt_text.162: Tibullus belongs eminently to that class of poets whose works reflect the form and colour of their own history.
tgt_text.163: His lot fell upon the evil days of his country, in which the remnant of its virtues perished with its rights.
tgt_text.164: A long series of civil wars and proscriptions had produced that general dissoluteness of manners which invariably attends uncertainty of life and property;
tgt_text.165: Eastern conquests had filled Rome with the accumulated wealth, and polluted her with the vices, of enslaved nations.
tgt_text.166: Had her freedom survived, the old Roman spirit might yet have rallied ;
tgt_text.167: but the one died out when the other was crushed under the despotism of Augustus.
tgt_text.168: The empire grew in might and majesty ;
tgt_text.169: but its men and women became daily viler;
tgt_text.170: and the refinement gained by imitation of foreign examples, though in itself a good thing, was a poor exchange for the honour and honesty of the rough old republican days;
tgt_text.171: for the racy freshness of home-grown habits, thoughts, feelings, and affections ;
tgt_text.172: for every native grace of life, lost for ever.
tgt_text.173: Imagine a man like Tibullus cast upon such times as those, —a man of instinctive elegance of mind, of extreme sensibility and warm affections, more given to contemplation than to action,-and you may go near to anticipate much of the general tone of those effusions in which his inward nature spontaneously reveals itself.
tgt_text.174: Add to this, that he was unhappy in love-how could he have been otherwise ?—less prosperous in fortune than in early youth he had reason to expect, a member of a de­ feated party, and faithful to the memory of a ruined cause ;
tgt_text.175: and we shall more clearly discern the sources of that tender melancholy which is his habitual mood, and of those changeful and often impulsive emotions that break its even flow, but always subside into it and leave it as before.
tgt_text.176: III at ef.se among the realities of the life that surrounded him, he flew to na­ ture, the perpetual nurse of wounded spirits, and animating his solitude with the traditions of the past, he lived in an ideal world.
tgt_text.177: A relish for the delights of the country was a national characteristic of the Romans;
tgt_text.178: in him it had the force of a passion.

tgt_text.184: His subjects, method, diction, and tone, are all his own.

tgt_text.191: Separately, considered, each piece is re­ markable for the copious variety of its thoughts and images, as well as for the subtlety of the links by which it is made to cohere in the smoothest and most unconstrained manner.

tgt_text.801: As a flower grows sequestered in a fenced garden, unknown to the cattle, bruised by no ploughshare, whilst the breezes freshen it, the sun gives it strength, and the shower nourishes it;

tgt_text.804: So whilst the virgin remains untouched, she is dear to her kindred;

tgt_text.807: As the unwedded vine which grows in a naked field, never lifts its head, never matures a mellow grape, but bending prone its tender body under its own weight, touches its top­ most shoot with its root;

tgt_text.809: but if perchance it be united with a husband elm, many hinds, many herdsmen cherish it:
tgt_text.810: so the virgin, whilst she remains untouched, grows old, uncared for;
tgt_text.811: when she has secured a fit union in due season, she is dearer to her spouse, and less irksome to her parent.

tgt_text.2417: WHAT avails it, Nerera, to have wearied the gods with vows, and to have offered them pleasing incense with many prayers ?
tgt_text.2418: I have not done this that I might issue forth from a marble mansion, as the distinguished scion of an illustrious house;
tgt_text.2419: or that my oxen might till many acres of land, and the kindly earth yield me large crops ;
tgt_text.2420: but that I might share with you the joys of a long life, and that my age might sink to rest on your bosom, when I should have completed my allotted span of life, and should be compelled to be ferried naked in the Lethæan boat.
tgt_text.2421: For what were I the better for a vast weight of gold ?
tgt_text.2422: Or though a thousand oxen tilled my fertile land ?
tgt_text.2423: What to me were a mansion supported on Phrygian columns, or on those from your quarries, Tænarus or Caristus ?2

tgt_text.2584: But whatever my Muses may avail to do, whether they can match thy glory, or, surpass it, which I have no hope of, or fall short, and they will certainly fall short of it, I will de­ dicate all this song to thee, that my poem may not want the dignity of thy great name.
tgt_text.2585: Though thou hast inherited the abundant renown of thy ancient race, thy glory was not content with ancestral fame;
tgt_text.2586: nor dost thou inquire only what the inscription states beneath each bust, but thou strivest to surpass the old honour of thy line, and to shed more lustre on thy ancestors than they on thee.
tgt_text.2587: But not the inscription alone beneath thy image, shall contain thy deeds, but great volumes shall be filled for thee with immortal verse ;
tgt_text.2588: and writers will spring up oil all sides to celebrate thee in verse and prose.

tgt_text.2645: For the earth is seated in the midst of the ambient air, and its whole orb is divided into five parts;
tgt_text.2646: and two of these are always made waste by icy cold.
tgt_text.2647: There the ground is always covered with thick mist, and the flowing wave is arrested in its course by frost, and stiffens into dense ice and snow;
tgt_text.2648: for Titan has never carried his beams above those regions.
tgt_text.2649: But the middle region is always exposed to the heat of Phoebus, whether he approaches nearer the earth in his summer orbit, or hurries swiftly through the short days of winter.
tgt_text.2650: There therefore the earth is not thrown up by the ploughshare, nor does it yield corn-crops or fodder.
tgt_text.2651: Neither Bacchus nor Ceres blesses the fields, nor do animals inhabit the scorched region.
tgt_text.2652: Be­ tween it and the cold regions are placed the two fertile zones, our own and that which is opposite to it.
tgt_text.2653: Both these are tempered alike by the climate that adjoins them on either hand, in such wise that the one climate counteracts the other.
tgt_text.2654: Hence the year revolves for us through mild seasons;
tgt_text.2655: hence the bull has learned to submit his neck to the yoke, and the flexible vine to ascend the lofty branches of the elm;
tgt_text.2656: the annual crop yields mature harvests, the earth is cleft with steel, the sea with the keel, and towns arise with walls of masonry.

tgt_text.4274: With earthward bend around their twisted roots, Nor herd nor peasant, in the noon-day heat, Beneath its chequer'd, bow'ry shade retreat:
tgt_text.4275: But if it clasp some elm with married leaves, Its shade the peasant and the herd receives :

tgt_text.4290: ELTONBORNE swiftly o'er the seas to Phrygia's woody strand, Atys with rapid haste infuriate leap'd to land;
tgt_text.4291: Where high-inwoven groves in solemn darkness meet, Rush'd to the mighty deity's remote and awful seat, And wilder'd in his brain, fierce inspiration's prey, There with a broken flint he struck his sex away.
tgt_text.4292: Soon as he then beheld his comely form unmann'd,
tgt_text.4293: While yet the purple blood flow'd reeking on the land Seized in his snowy grasp the drum, the timbrel light, That still is heard, dread Cybele, at thine initiate rite, And struck the quivering skin, whence hollow echoes flew, And raised this panting song to his infuriate crew."
tgt_text.4294: Ye priests of Cybele, or rather let me say, For ye are men no longer, ye priestesses, away !
tgt_text.4295: Together pierce the forest, great Cybele's domains, Ye vagrant flocks of her on Dindymus who reigns.
tgt_text.4296: Ye, like devoted exiles, who, seeking foreign lands, Have follow'd me your leader, have bow'd to my commands ;
tgt_text.4297: Have cross'd the salt-sea wave, have dared the raging storms, And, loathing woman's love, unmann'd your lusty forms;
tgt_text.4298: The sense of error past let laughing frenzy blind;
tgt_text.4299: Let doubt, let thought itself be driven from the mind.
tgt_text.4300: Haste, haste, together haste to Cybele divine !
tgt_text.4301: Seek we her Phrygian grove and dark sequester'd shrine, Where cymbals clash, where drums resound their deepening tone, Where Phrygia's crooked pipe breathes out its solemn drone, Where votaresses toss their ivy-circled brows, And urge with piercing yells their consecrated vows, Where the delirious train disport as chance may lead:
tgt_text.4302: Thither our vows command in mystic dance to speed.
tgt_text.4303: "Thus Atys, female now, to female comrades sung.
tgt_text.4304: The frantic chorus rose from many a panting tongue;
tgt_text.4305: He-echoes the deep timbrel, the hollow cymbals ring, And all to verdant Ida run madly as they sing.
tgt_text.4306: Though breathless, still impetuous with inspiration's force, Raving and bewilder'd, scarce conscious of her course, As the unbroken heifer will By the threaten'd yoke, Atys through gloomy woods, where never sun-beam broke, Loud-striking the light timbrel, rush'd on with bounding stride, And all the frantic priestesses pursue their rapid guide.
tgt_text.4307: The fearful fane at length their panting ardour stops, Each, faint and unrefresh'd, in leaden slumber drops.
tgt_text.4308: In languor most profound their eyelids are deprest, And all ecstatic rage is lull'd in torpid rest.

tgt_text.4310: Put forth his golden brow, when now his radiant eyes Throughout white heaven, and earth, and ocean pour'd their light, And with thunder-pacing steeds he chased the shades of night, Sleep then leaving Atys, who started from her rest, To fair Pasithea fled, and sunk upon her breast.
tgt_text.4311: When slumber's reign serene had frenzy's flame subdued ;
tgt_text.4312: When Atys her fell deed in clearer reason view'd, Beheld in what abode her future lot was placed, And, ah !
tgt_text.4313: how low she stood in nature's rank disgraced ;
tgt_text.4314: Then, hurried to despair by passion's rising tide, Again she wildly sought the country's sea-girt side ;
tgt_text.4315: There, casting her full eyes o'er boundless ocean's flow, Address'd her native land in plaintive words of woe."

tgt_text.4332: With blooming garlands hung, that lovesick maidens form'd;

tgt_text.4340: And thus to fury waked the tyrant of the fold."

tgt_text.4349: Gladly the beast awakes his ruthlessness of mind, Bounds, rages, reckless leaves the thicket crush'd behind, Then swiftly gained the beach, washed by the foamy flood, Where Atys in despair amid the breakers stood, And springing fiercely forth-the wretch, no longer brave, Into the forest plunged, and in a living grave There pass'd her long devoted life, a priestess and a slave.0 great, 0 fearful goddess !

tgt_text.4354: LAMB.ATYS o'er the distant waters, driving in his rapid, bark, Soon with foot of wild impatience touched the Phrygian forest dark, Where amid the awful shades possessed by mighty Cybele, In his zealous frenzy blind, And wand'ring in his hapless mind, With flinty knife he gave to earth the weights that stamp virility.

tgt_text.4357: And upon its whirling fingers, while the hollow parchment rung, Thus in outcry tremulous to its wild companions sung:
tgt_text.4359: Now come along, come along with me, Worshippers of Cybele, To the lofty groves of the deity!

tgt_text.4362: Who seeking strange lands, like the banish'd of home, With Atys, with Atys distractedly roam ;

tgt_text.4364: Who have carried my sect through the dreadful salt sea, Rouse, rouse your wild spirits careeringly !

tgt_text.4366: Where the ivy-crown'd priestesses toss with their brows, And send the shrill howl through their deity's house ;

tgt_text.4503: Then rush'd, her ankles naked to the breeze, Amid the breakers of repelling seas, And there with half-drawn sighs, and meanings faint, And streaming eyes, pour'd forth this wild complaint."
tgt_text.4504: And hast thou, Theseus, on this desert strand Left her, who fled for thee my native land;
tgt_text.4505: And has thy double perfidy beguiled
tgt_text.4506: The trusting father to betray the child ?
tgt_text.4507: Darest thou, in scorn of heaven's attested host, Bear fated perjury to thy native coast ?
tgt_text.4508: Could nothing cheek the deed thy soul design'd;
tgt_text.4509: Did rising pity never touch thy mind;
tgt_text.4510: Nor e'er thy bosom to itself pourtray
tgt_text.4511: Those burning pangs that now make mine their prey ?
tgt_text.4512: Not these thy promises so fondly vow'd,
tgt_text.4513: When all affections to thine accent bow'd :
tgt_text.4514: Thou never bad'st me hope a fate like this, But festive spousals and connubial bliss.
tgt_text.4515: The oaths thy passion urged thee then to swear Are now all scattered to the senseless air.
tgt_text.4516: Then let no woman hence in man believe, Or think a lover speaks but to deceive.
tgt_text.4517: He, while ungratified desire is high, Shrinks from no oath, no promise will deny ;
tgt_text.4518: Soon as his lust is satiate with its prize, He spurns his vows and perjury's curse defies.

tgt_text.4522: nor shall remorse Heap e'en the rudest grave upon my corse."

tgt_text.4525: Though by the will of thy harsh father tied
tgt_text.4526: Thou couldst not wed, and hail me as thy bride;
tgt_text.4527: Thou might'st have borne me to thy native soil, And I, thine handmaid, plied my pleasing toil;
tgt_text.4528: O'er thy fair feet the tepid stream have shed, And smoothed the purple covering of thy bed."

tgt_text.4530: Which with no sense endowed, no feeling warm, Nor hears my utterance, nor can answer form ?

tgt_text.4532: No man, no creature treads the silent beach.

tgt_text.4541: Shall I my native mountains seek again ?
tgt_text.4543: the wide depth of ocean's pathless roar Bars my approach ;
tgt_text.4544: and dare I hope once more
tgt_text.4545: My sire's affection, whom I left to wed
tgt_text.4546: The reeking murderer of my brother dead ?
tgt_text.4547: Can love's sweet musings any solace give, Or pictured truth, or promised rapture live ;
tgt_text.4548: When the dear youth, on whom this heart relied, Forsakes my bed and flies o'er yonder tide ?
tgt_text.4549: No home, no busy cots around me smile, And seas confine me to this hapless isle.
tgt_text.4550: No means, no hope of flight, no living breath, All round is desert, but all big with death."
tgt_text.4551: But yet, ere fate shall close my languid eye, Ere from my woe-worn breast my senses fly ;
tgt_text.4552: I from the gods some ample curse will claim

tgt_text.5933: The choicest falling then could richly yield;
tgt_text.5934: Now scarce I spare a little lamb to bleed A mighty victim for my scanty field.
tgt_text.5935: And yet a lamb shall bleed, while, ranged around, The village youths shall stand in order meet, With rustic hymns, ye gods, your praise resound, And future crops and future wines entreat,Then come, ye powers, nor scorn my frugal board, Nor yet the gifts clean earthen bowls convey;
tgt_text.5936: With these the first of men the gods adored, And form'd their simple shape of ductile clay.
tgt_text.5937: My little flock, ye wolves, ye robbers, spare, Too mean a plunder to deserve your toil;
tgt_text.5938: For wealthier herds the nightly theft prepare;
tgt_text.5939: There seek a nobler prey, and richer spoil.
tgt_text.5940: For treasured wealth, nor stores of golden wheat, The hoard of frugal sires, I vainly call;
tgt_text.5941: A little farm be mine, a cottage neat, And wonted couch where balmy sleep may falL
tgt_text.5942: “What joy to hear the tempest howl in vain, And clasp a fearful mistress to my breast;
tgt_text.5943: Or lull'd to slumber by the beating rain, Secure and happy sink at last to rest.
tgt_text.5944: "These joys be mine !—0 grant me only these, And give to others bags of shining gold, Whose steely heart can brave the boist'rous seas, The storm wide-wasting, or the stiffening cold.
tgt_text.5945: Content with little, I would rather stay Than spend long months amid the wat'ry waste;
tgt_text.5946: In cooling shades elude the scorching ray, Beside some fountain's gliding waters placed.
tgt_text.5947: Oh perish rather all that's rich and rare, The diamond quarry, and the golden vein, Than that my absence cost one precious tear, Or give some gentle maid a moment's pain.
tgt_text.5948: With glittering spoils, Messala, gild thy dome, Be thine the noble task to lead the brave ;
tgt_text.5949: A lovely foe me captive holds at home, Chain'd to her scornful gate, a watchful slave.
tgt_text.5950: Inglorious post!-and yet I heed not fame :
tgt_text.5951: Th' applause of crowds for Delia I'd resign:
tgt_text.5952: To live with thee I'd bear the coward's name, Nor 'midst the scorn of nations once repine.
tgt_text.5953: With thee to live I'd mock the ploughman's toil.
tgt_text.5954: Or on some lonely mountain tend my sheep ;
tgt_text.5955: At night I'd lay me on the flinty soil, And happy 'midst thy dear embraces sleep.
tgt_text.5956: What drooping lover heeds the Tyrian bed, While the long night is pass'd with many a sigh;
tgt_text.5957: Nor softest down with richest carpets spread, Nor whisp'ring rills can close the weeping eye.
tgt_text.5958: Of threefold iron were his rugged frame, Who, when he might thy yielding heart obtain, Could yet attend the calls of empty fame, Or follow arms in quest of sordid gain.
tgt_text.5959: Unenvied let him drive the vanquish'd host, Through captive lands his conquering armies lead ;
tgt_text.5960: Unenvied wear the robe with gold emboss'cl, And guide with solemn state his foaming steed.
tgt_text.5961: Oh may I view thee with life's parting ray, And thy dear hand with dying ardour press:
tgt_text.5962: Sure thou wilt weep-and on thy lover's clay, With breaking heart, print many a tender kiss !
tgt_text.5963: Sure thou wilt weep-and woes unntter’d feel, When on the pile thou seest thy lover laid !
tgt_text.5964: For well I know, nor flint, nor ruthless steel, Can arm the breast of such a gentle maid.
tgt_text.5965: From the sad pomp, what youth, what pitying fair, Returning slow, can tender tears refrain ?
tgt_text.5966: O Delia, spare thy cheeks, thy tresses spare, Nor give my ling'ring shade a world of pain.
tgt_text.5967: But now while smiling hours the Fates bestow, Let love, dear maid, our gentle hearts unite !
tgt_text.5968: Soon death will come and strike the fatal blow;
tgt_text.5969: Unseen his head, and veil'd in shades of night.
tgt_text.5970: Soon creeping age will bow the lover's frame, And tear the myrtle chaplet from his brow:
tgt_text.5971: With hoary locks ill suits the youthful flame, The soft persuasion, or the ardent vow.
tgt_text.5972: Now the fair queen of gay desire is ours,
tgt_text.5973: And lends our follies an indulgent smile :
tgt_text.5974: 'Tis lavish youth's t' enjoy the frolic hours, The wanton revel and the midnight broil.
tgt_text.5975: Your chief, my friends and fellow-soldiers, I To these light wars will lead you boldly on:
tgt_text.5976: Far hence, ye trumpets, sound, and banners fly;
tgt_text.5977: To those who covet wounds and fame begone.
tgt_text.5978: And bear them fame and wounds ;
tgt_text.5980: There are that fame and wounds and riches prize.
tgt_text.5981: For me, while I possess one plenteous year, I'll wealth and meagre want alike despise.
tgt_text.5982: GRAINGER.LET others raise enormous heaps of gold,
tgt_text.5983: And by sure tenure numerous acres hold ;
tgt_text.5984: Whom daily fears of neighbouring foes affright, While the shrill trumpet breaks their sleep at night.
tgt_text.5985: Me let my easy poverty release From anxious cares, in liberty and ease ;
tgt_text.5986: While my glad hearth with daily fires is bright, And slumbers, undisturbed with cares, at night, Still let the seasons crown my smiling field, Of kindly fruits a plenteous harvest yield.
tgt_text.5987: Still may the product of my loaded vine
tgt_text.5988: Swell all my vessels with nectareous wine.
tgt_text.5989: Myself th' industrious husbandman will be, And set with ready hand the apple tree;
tgt_text.5990: And in due season plant the tender vine;
tgt_text.5991: Nor e'er the joys of solitude resign.
tgt_text.5992: Nor shall I blush the rustic fork to wield, Or goad the sluggish ox to plough the field;
tgt_text.5993: Or in my arms to bear the straggling lamb, Or tender kid, home to the mourning dam.
tgt_text.5994: With rural rites my careful shepherd here I'm used to lustrate each revolving year;
tgt_text.5995: Propitious sacred Pales to retain, I sprinkle milk upon the rising grain.
tgt_text.5996: For still I worship wheresoe'er I see An ancient stone, or remnant of a tree, With flowery garlands crown'd in open field, Or where three ways decisive limits yield.
tgt_text.5997: The rural gods as offerings shall receive
tgt_text.5998: The earliest fruit my loaded orchards give.
tgt_text.5999: Thy temple gates, 0 Ceres, I '11 adorn With auburn wreaths of ripen'd ears of corn.
tgt_text.6000: And in my orchard let Priapus stand With the dire sickle in his ruddy hand, To scare the noxious birds from off my land.
tgt_text.6001: And you, my household gods, shall have your due, More spreading fields were once preserved by you.
tgt_text.6002: The guardians once of large extended plains, Now one small farm your kind protection gains.
tgt_text.6003: A cow-calf then for numerous herds of kine Fell a lustration to your powers divine.
tgt_text.6004: A lambkin now at your blessed altar dies, Of narrow soil the mighty sacrifice.
tgt_text.6005: A lambkin to your deities shall fall, While round the rustic youths on you shall call. "
tgt_text.6006: Good harvest and good vintage, oh !
tgt_text.6008: Harvest and vintage to your smiles we owe.
tgt_text.6011: To take the off'rings of a lowly swain, Though such small earthen vessels them contain.
tgt_text.6012: The swains of old in earthen bowls caroused, E'er glittering gold or silver yet were used.
tgt_text.6013: And you, ye thieves and wolves, my flock refrain, Your prey from larger herds you'll easier gain.
tgt_text.6014: My father's wealth's below my just desire, Or the full granaries of his potent sire.
tgt_text.6015: A little crop my wishes will supply, It is enough upon my couch to lie.
tgt_text.6016: Let me on that my wearied limbs repose, And give a toilsome grandeur to my foes.
tgt_text.6017: On that reclined, how pleasing 'tis to hear
tgt_text.6018: The winds inclement make tumultuous war, Clasping within my arms my clinging fair !
tgt_text.6019: Or when, by winter's cold congeal'd, the rain, In rattling showers assaults my hut in vain.
tgt_text.6020: Delia and I secure to slumbers haste, Lull'd by the rocking storms and winter's blast
tgt_text.6023: Who can the fury of the billows dare, And, patient of the weather, tempests bear.
tgt_text.6024: My wishes move within a narrow bound, Content at last with little I have found.
tgt_text.6025: The tedious paths to wealth no more I'll stray, My easy soul abhors that rugged way.
tgt_text.6026: Beneath the shadow of some spreading tree, From fear, from hope, from toil, from wishes free, Upon the brink of a cool tumbling stream, I shun the dog-star's fierce and sultry gleam.
tgt_text.6028: perish rather, all ye glittering gold, And jewels which fond mortals precious hold, Than any tender she let fall a tear, Struck, by the danger of my ways, with fear !
tgt_text.6029: In thee, Messala, war has wondrous charms, While land and sea are conquer'd by thy arms;
tgt_text.6030: When as the crown of all thy glorious toils, Thou seest thy house adorn'd with hostile spoils Bound with Love's fetters, here will I remain, I cannot break soft beauty's lovely chain.
tgt_text.6031: No lust of praise invades my peaceful breast, Whilst thus with thee, my Delia, I am blest.
tgt_text.6032: Of sloth and idleness I court the fame;
tgt_text.6033: Thou art a solid good, that but a name.
tgt_text.6034: If thou, my Delia, still with me remain, To yoke the steers myself affords no pain.
tgt_text.6035: I can, when thou art by, on lonely downs
tgt_text.6036: Feed my own herds, secure from Delia's frowns, While thee I can within my bosom keep, I on the rugged ground can calmly sleep.
tgt_text.6037: Of what avail are Tyrian beds of down, When love averse will only give a frown ?
tgt_text.6038: The tedious night in tears will slowly move, The joys of night we only owe to love.
tgt_text.6039: 'Tis not the down, nor yet the Tyrian loom, Nor all the golden carpets of thy room, Nor the soft murmurs of the water's fall, Can to thy rescue gentle slumbers call.
tgt_text.6042: Who can have thee within his happy bed, And yet would leave thee for the dire alarms (In chase of spoils) of horrid martial arms :
tgt_text.6043: Though his victorious troops subdue the foe,.
tgt_text.6044: And wait his nod where'er he please to go;
tgt_text.6045: Though clad in silver, cover'd o'er with gold, Upon his prancing horse, most graceful to behold
tgt_text.6046: Thee let me view when I resign my breath, Thee let me grasp e'en in the pangs of death;
tgt_text.6047: And press, with fah'ring hands, thy lovely arms, In death my Delia still would have her charms.
tgt_text.6048: You'd weep, my Delia, when you saw me die, Beheld me on my bed expiring lie;
tgt_text.6049: On my cold lips thy kisses thou wouldst fix, While flowing tears with thy dear kisses mix.
tgt_text.6050: Yes, you would weep, you would let fall a tear;
tgt_text.6051: Those lovely eyes a drooping grief would wear.
tgt_text.6052: I know thee well, all tenderness thou art, Nor steel, nor stone, in thee have any part, But love and soft compassion fill thy heart.
tgt_text.6053: No, from my funeral no kind youth would go, Nor tender virgin, ere their tears did flow.
tgt_text.6054: Spare, spare my Manes, gentle Delia, spare
tgt_text.6055: Thy lovely locks, thy bright, dishevell'd hair, And violence to that dear face forbear.
tgt_text.6056: While fate permits, then let us join our loves, Death with his gloomy brow too swiftly moves;
tgt_text.6057: And feeble age steals on, when love will be Indecent and in vain in thee and me.
tgt_text.6058: With hoary hairs soft toys will not agree.
tgt_text.6059: Now is the time bright Venus to enjoy, And taste the pleasures of the wanton boy.
tgt_text.6060: While youth is high, the pretty strifes of love, Its war and peace, a sweet delight will move.
tgt_text.6061: In this a soldier's merit I may claim, And e'en a general's more exalted fame:
tgt_text.6062: Far hence, ye ensigns ! far, ye trumpets' sounds, To those who court them bear your blood and wounds , Bear to the same the heaps of gold away, For gold and fame I yield their sordid prey.
tgt_text.6063: Pleased with my present store, securely wise, Hunger and wealth I equally despise.
tgt_text.6064: OTWAY.LET others pile their yellow ingots high,
tgt_text.6065: And see their cultured acres round them spread;
tgt_text.6066: While hostile borderers draw their anxious eye, And at the trumpet's blast their sleep is fled.
tgt_text.6067: Me let my poverty to ease resign;
tgt_text.6068: While my bright hearth reflects its blazing cheer;
tgt_text.6069: In season let me plant the pliant vine, And, with light hand, my swelling apples rear.
tgt_text.6072: Let the brimm'd vat flow red with virgin wine:
tgt_text.6073: For still some lone bare stump that marks the field, Or antique cross-way stone, with flowers I twine,In pious rite;
tgt_text.6074: and, when the year anew Matures the blossom on the budding spray, I bear the peasant's god his grateful due, And firstling fruits upon his altar lay.
tgt_text.6075: Still let thy temple's porch, 0 Ceres !
tgt_text.6077: The spiky garland from my harvest field;
tgt_text.6078: And, 'midst my orchard, 'gainst the birds of air, His threatening hook let red Priapus wield.
tgt_text.6079: Ye too, once guardians of a rich domain, Now of poor fields, domestic gods !be kind.

tgt_text.6081: Now to your altars is a lamb consigned.

tgt_text.6083: While round it shout the youthful sons of toil, " Hail!

tgt_text.6087: The lengthening road, but shun the summer day, Where some o'er-branching tree might shade my head, And watch the murmuring rivulet glide away.
tgt_text.6088: Nor could I blush to wield the rustic prong, The lingering oxen goad;
tgt_text.6089: or some stray lamb, Embosom'd in my garment, bear along, Or kid forgotten by its heedless dam.

tgt_text.6101: Their garners' floors with sheafy corn bespread ;
tgt_text.6104: To lay my limbs upon th' accustomed bed.
tgt_text.6105: How sweet to hear, without, the howling blast, And strain a yielding mistress to my breast!
tgt_text.6106: Or, when the gusty torrent's rush has past, Sink, lull'd by beating rains, to shelter'd rest!

tgt_text.6114: I heed not praise, my Delia !
tgt_text.6116: Sloth brand my name, so I thy sight behold ;
tgt_text.6119: On desert mountains I will feed my fold.
tgt_text.6120: And, while I press'd thee in my tender arms, Sweet were my slumber on the rugged ground:
tgt_text.6121: What boots the purple couch, if cruel charms
tgt_text.6122: In wakeful tears the midnight hours have drown'd?
tgt_text.6123: Not the soft plume can yield the limbs repose, Nor yet the broider'd covering soothe to sleep;
tgt_text.6124: Not the calm streamlet that in murmurs flows, With sound oblivious o'er the eyelids creep.

tgt_text.6126: What though his spear Cilieian squadrons press, What though his tent be pitch'd on conquer'd plains ?
tgt_text.6127: In gold and silver mail conspicuous he May stride the steed, that, pawing, spurs the sand;
tgt_text.6128: May I my last looks fondly bend on thee, And grasp thee with my dying, faltering hand !
tgt_text.6129: And thou wilt weep when, cold, I press the bier, That soon shall on the flaming pyre be thrown ;
tgt_text.6130: And print the kiss, and mingle many a tear;
tgt_text.6131: Not thine a breast of steel, a heart of stone.

tgt_text.6134: But thou forbear to violate my urn, Spare thy soft cheeks, nor those loose tresses rend.
tgt_text.6135: Now fate permits, now blend the sweet embrace:
tgt_text.6136: Death, cowl'd in darkness, creeps with stealing tread , III suits with sluggish age love’s sprightly grace, And murmur'd fondness with a hoary head.

tgt_text.6143: Wealth I despise in easy competence.
tgt_text.6144: ELTON.IRON were he, who, when he could possess
tgt_text.6145: Thy charms, preferr'd renown to happiness.
tgt_text.6146: Though decked with spoils, the guerdon of the brave, O'er conquer’d lands he bids his banners wave.
tgt_text.6147: Though captive monarchs throng his sounding car, And bow beneath that thunderbolt of war.
tgt_text.6148: I envy not the blood-stain'd hero's pride, Content to feed my flocks at Delia's side.
tgt_text.6149: If thou art with me, oh !
tgt_text.6151: Though doom'd to turn for bread a thankless soil!
tgt_text.6152: On the cold hill to lay my pensive head, If thou art with me, oh !
tgt_text.6154: What joy remains, when gentle love has flown ?
tgt_text.6155: On downy pillows, wretched and alone, Still through the night the sons of fortune weep, Nor gold, ner blushing purple, brings them sleep;
tgt_text.6156: Celestial music pours a fruitless strain, Murmur soft airs and fountains flow in vain.
tgt_text.6157: HODGSON.WITH wine, more wine, my recent pains deceive, Till creeping slumber send a soft reprieve :
tgt_text.6158: Asleep, take heed no whisper stirs the air, For waked, my boy, I wake to heart-felt care.
tgt_text.6159: Now is my Delia watch'd by ruthless spies, And the gate, bolted, all access denies.

tgt_text.6162: With mingled violence avenge my pain !
tgt_text.6163: May forky thunders, hurl’d by Jove's red hand, Burst every bolt, and shatter every band !
tgt_text.6167: On me, devoted, let the thunder fall!
tgt_text.6168: Then recollect my many wreaths of yore, How oft you've seen me weep, insensate door!
tgt_text.6169: No longer then our interview delay, And as you open let no noise betray.
tgt_text.6170: In vain I plead !-dare then my Delia rise !
tgt_text.6171: Love aids the dauntless, and will blind your spies!
tgt_text.6172: Those who the godhead's soft behests obey, Steal from their pillows unobserv'd away ;
tgt_text.6173: On tip-toe traverse unobserv'd the floor ;
tgt_text.6174: The key turn noiseless, and unfold the door:
tgt_text.6175: In vain the jealous each precaution take, Their speaking fingers assignations make.
tgt_text.6176: Nor will the god impart to all his aid:
tgt_text.6177: Love hates the fearful, hates the lazy maid ;
tgt_text.6178: But through sly windings and unpractis'd ways
tgt_text.6179: His bold knight-errants to their wish conveys:
tgt_text.6180: For those whom he with expectation fires
tgt_text.6181: No ambush frightens, and no labour tires;
tgt_text.6182: Sacred the dangers of the dark they dare, No robbers stop them, and no bravoes scare.
tgt_text.6183: Though wintry tempests howl, by love secure, The howling tempest I with ease endure:
tgt_text.6184: No watching hurts me, if my Delia smile, Soft turn the gate, aud beckon me the while.
tgt_text.6186: Be blind, ye ramblers of the night, Lest angry Venus snatch your guilty sight:
tgt_text.6187: The goddess bids her votaries'joys to be From every casual interruption free :
tgt_text.6188: With prying steps alarm us not, retire, Nor glare your torches, nor our names inquire:
tgt_text.6189: Or if ye know, deny, by heaven above, Nor dare divulge the privacies of love.
tgt_text.6190: From blood and seas vindictive Venus sprung, And sure destruction waits the blabbing tongue !
tgt_text.6191: Nay, should they prate, you, Delia, need not fear;
tgt_text.6192: Your lord (a sorceress swore) should give no ear !
tgt_text.6193: By potent spells she cleaves the sacred ground, And shuddering spectres wildly roam around !
tgt_text.6194: I've seen her tear the planets from the sky !
tgt_text.6195: Seen lightning backward at her bidding fly !
tgt_text.6197: from blazing pyres the corse descends, And, re-enliven’d, clasps his wondering friends !
tgt_text.6198: The friends she gathers with a magic yell, Then with aspersions frights them back to hell!
tgt_text.6199: She wills,—glad summer gilds the frozen pole !
tgt_text.6200: She wills,-in summer wintry tempests roll!
tgt_text.6201: She knows ('tis true) Medea’s awful spell!
tgt_text.6202: She knows to vanquish the fierce guards of hell!
tgt_text.6203: To me she gave a charm for lovers meet, (" Spit thrice, my fair, and thrice the charm repeat.”)
tgt_text.6204: Us in soft dalliance should your lord surprise, By this imposed on he'd renounce his eyes !
tgt_text.6205: But bless no rival, or th' affair is known ;
tgt_text.6208: but swore, if I'd agree, By charms or herbs to set thy lover free.
tgt_text.6209: With dire lustrations she began the rite !
tgt_text.6210: (Serenely shone the planet of the night,)
tgt_text.6211: The magic gods she call'd with hellish sound, A sable sacrifice distain'd the ground— I stopp'd the spell:
tgt_text.6213: I begg'd her aid to gain a mutual heart.
tgt_text.6216: give me wine, to heal my wounded breast, And close my aching eyes in pleasant rest.
tgt_text.6217: Let not a sound disturb the blissful bed, Where love itself lies tranquil as the dead.

tgt_text.6224: And thy bright pillars hung with living flowers.

tgt_text.6226: Venus herself the dauntless pair rewards ;
tgt_text.6227: And helps the boy who jealous walls explores, And helps the girl who opes forbidden doors!

tgt_text.6229: Such arts are theirs who fly from sluggard ease, Cross the dark moor, and in the tempest freeze, Till, safely nestling in their fair one's arms, They feel the glowing change exalt her charms.
tgt_text.6230: No lawless robber in my path shall rove, For sacred is the messenger of love ;
tgt_text.6231: Nor storm nor howling rain shall cloud my road, If Delia beckon to the dear abode;
tgt_text.6232: Draw the soft bolt, and silently advise
tgt_text.6233: My sounding footsteps with her fearful eyes, With eager finger on her lip imprest, Impatient brow, and quickly-beating breast.
tgt_text.6234: Veil, veil your lamps, whoever travel nigh, The thefts of Venus shun the curious eye.
tgt_text.6235: Nor tread too loudly, nor inquire my name, Nor to my face advance your taper's flame.
tgt_text.6236: And ye, who chance to see, the sight forswear, And vow by all the gods ye were not there.
tgt_text.6237: The prating babbler shall confess with pain That Venus issued from the savage main.
tgt_text.6238: Nay, e'en your lord the tell-tale shall distrust, And scorn the lying rumour of your lust.
tgt_text.6239: So sang the witch, whose prophecy divine Assured my hopes, and made thee wholly mine.
tgt_text.6240: She draws the stars from heaven with influence strong, And turns the course of rapid streams by song ;
tgt_text.6241: Cleaves the firm ground, the dead with life inspires, Bids rattling bones start forth from burial fires, With magic yell the gathering ghosts commands, Or purifies with milk their parting bands.
tgt_text.6242: Wills she—the clouds of thunder disappear !
tgt_text.6243: Wills she—dark whirlwinds overcast the sphere !
tgt_text.6244: Sole mistress she of dire Medea's charms, Her power alone the dogs of hell disarms.
tgt_text.6245: A rhyme she framed, which if thou thrice rehearse, Thy lord shall yield such homage to the verse, That not a tale his spies relate of me, No, nor the hot embrace his eyes may see, Shall win his faith-but if my rivals dare
tgt_text.6246: To snatch the slightest favour from my fair, Her jealous lord shall every theft perceive, Know all lie suffers, all he hears believe.
tgt_text.6247: Shall I too trust the sorceress' potent art, By herb, or song, to free my captive heart?
tgt_text.6248: The lustral torches blazed at midnight hour, Fell the black victim to each magic power, And thus I pray’d—“Oh !
tgt_text.6250: But Delia's breast with mutual fondness move !
tgt_text.6251: I would not wish for freedom from my pains, Oh !
tgt_text.6252: what were life unless I wore her chains !”
tgt_text.6253: HODGSON.WITH wine, more wine, deceive thy master's care, Till creeping slumber soothe his troubled breast;
tgt_text.6254: Let not a whisper stir the silent air, If hapless love a while consent to rest.
tgt_text.6255: Untoward guards beset my Cynthia's doors, And cruel locks th' imprison'd fair conceal.
tgt_text.6256: May lightnings blast whom love in vain implores, And Jove's own thunder rive those bolts of steeLAh, gentle door, attend my humble call, Nor let thy sounding hinge our thefts betray;
tgt_text.6257: So all my curses far from thee shall fall.
tgt_text.6258: We angry lovers mean not half we say.
tgt_text.6259: Remember now the flowery wreaths I gave, When first I told thee of my bold desires ;
tgt_text.6260: Nor thou, 0 Cynthia, fear the watchful slave, Venus will favour what herself inspires.
tgt_text.6261: She guides the youth who see not where they tread ;
tgt_text.6262: She shows the virgin how to turn the door, Softly to steal from off her silent bed, And not a step betray her on the floor.
tgt_text.6263: The fearless lover wants no beam of light;
tgt_text.6264: The robber knows him, nor obstructs his way;
tgt_text.6265: Sacred he wanders through the pathless night, Belongs to Venus, and can never stray.
tgt_text.6266: I scorn the chilling wind and beating rain, Nor heed cold watchings on the dewy ground, If all the hardships I for love sustain, With love's victorious joys at last be crown'd:
tgt_text.6267: With sudden step let none our bliss surprise, Or check the freedom of secure delight-
tgt_text.6268: Rash man, beware, and shut thy curious eyes, Lest angry Venus snatch their guilty sight.
tgt_text.6269: But shouldst thou see, th' important secret hide, Though questioned by the powers of earth and heaven
tgt_text.6270: The prating tongue shall love's revenge abide, Still sue for grace, and never be forgiven.
tgt_text.6271: A wizard dame, the lover's ancient friend, With magic charm has deaft thy husband's ear;
tgt_text.6272: At her command I saw the stars descend, And winged lightnings stop in mid career.
tgt_text.6273: I saw her stamp and cleave the solid ground, While ghastly spectres round us wildly roam ;
tgt_text.6274: I saw them hearken to her potent sound, Till, scared at day, they sought their dreary home.
tgt_text.6275: At her command the vigorous summer pines, And wintry clouds obscure the hopeful year;
tgt_text.6276: At her strong bidding, gloomy winter shines, And vernal roses on the snows appear.
tgt_text.6277: She gave these charms, which I on thee bestow;
tgt_text.6278: They dim the eye, and dull the jealous mind;
tgt_text.6279: For me they make a husband nothing know, For me, and only me, they make him blind.
tgt_text.6280: But what did most this faithful heart surprise, Site boasted that her skill could set it free:
tgt_text.6281: This faithful heart the boasted freedom flies;
tgt_text.6282: How could it venture to abandon thee ?
tgt_text.6283: HAMMOND.WHILE you, Messala, plough th' Ægean sea, Oh sometimes kindly deign to think of me:
tgt_text.6284: Me, hapless me, Phæacian shores detain, Unknown, unpitied, and oppress'd with pain.
tgt_text.6285: Yet spar.- me, death, ah spare me, and retire:
tgt_text.6286: No weeping mother's here to light my pyre:
tgt_text.6287: Here is no sister, with a sister's woe, Rich Syrian odours on the pile to throw:
tgt_text.6288: But chief, my soul's soft partner is not here, Her locks to loose, and sorrow o'er my bier.
tgt_text.6289: What though fair Delia my return implored, Each fane frequented, and each god adored ;
tgt_text.6290: What though they bade me every peril brave, And Fortune thrice auspicious omens gave;
tgt_text.6291: All could not dry my tender Delia's tears, Suppress her sighs, or calm her anxious fears;
tgt_text.6292: E'en as I strove to minister relief, Unconscious tears proclaim'd my heart-felt grief:
tgt_text.6293: Urged still to go, a thousand shifts I made, Birds now, now festivals my voyage stay'd:
tgt_text.6294: Or, if I struck my foot against the door, Straight I return'd, and wisdom was no more.
tgt_text.6295: Forbid by Cupid, let no swain depart;
tgt_text.6296: Cupid is vengeful, and will wring his heart.
tgt_text.6297: What do your offerings now, my fair, avail ?
tgt_text.6298: Your Isis heeds not, and your cymbals fail!
tgt_text.6299: What though array'd in sacred robes you stood, Fled man's embrace, and sought the purest flood?
tgt_text.6300: While this I write, I sensibly decay,­ " Assist me, Isis, drive my pains away :
tgt_text.6301: That you can every mortal ill remove, The numerous tablets in your temple prove:
tgt_text.6302: So shall my Delia, veil'd in votive white, Before your threshold sit for many a night;
tgt_text.6303: And twice a day, her tresses all unbound, Amid your votaries famed, your praises sound:
tgt_text.6304: Safe to my household gods may I return, And incense monthly on their altars burn.
tgt_text.6305: "How blest man liv'd in Saturn's golden days, E'er distant climes were join'd by lengthen’d waya
tgt_text.6306: Secure the pine upon the mountain grew, Nor yet o'er billows in the ocean flew;
tgt_text.6307: Then every clime a wild abundance bore, And man liv'd happy on his natal shore:
tgt_text.6308: For then no steed to feel the bit was broke.
tgt_text.6309: Then had no steer submitted to the yoke ;
tgt_text.6310: No house had gates, (blest times !) and, in the grounds,
tgt_text.6311: No scanty land-marks parcelled out the bounds:
tgt_text.6312: From every oak redundant honey ran,
tgt_text.6313: And ewes spontaneous bore their milk to man:
tgt_text.6314: No deathful arms were forged, no war was waged, No rapine plunder'd, no ambition raged.
tgt_text.6317: Gold fires the soul, and falchions arm our hands:
tgt_text.6318: Each day, the main unnumber’d lives destroys:
tgt_text.6319: And slaughter, daily, o'er her myriads joys.
tgt_text.6320: Yet spare me, Jove, I ne'er disowned thy sway, I ne'er was perjur'd ;
tgt_text.6322: But, if the Sisters have pronounced my doom, Inscribed be these upon my humble tomb.
tgt_text.6324: here inurn’d a youthful poet lies, Far from his Delia, and his native skies !
tgt_text.6325: Far from the lov'd Messala, whom to please Tibullus followed over land and seas.
tgt_text.6326: "Then Love my ghost (for Love I still obey'd)
tgt_text.6327: Will grateful usher to th' Elysian shade :
tgt_text.6328: There joy and ceaseless revelry prevail;
tgt_text.6329: There soothing music floats on every gale;
tgt_text.6330: There painted warblers hop from spray to spray, And, wildly-pleasing, swell the general lay:
tgt_text.6331: There every hedge, untaught, with cassia blooms, And scents the ambient air with rich perfumes:
tgt_text.6332: There every mead a various plenty yields ;
tgt_text.6333: There lavish Flora paints the purple fields:
tgt_text.6334: With ceaseless light a brighter Phœbus glows, No sickness tortures, and no ocean flows;
tgt_text.6335: But youths associate with the gentle fair, And stung with pleasure to the shade repair:
tgt_text.6336: With them Love wanders wheresoe'er they stray, Provokes to rapture, and inflames the play:
tgt_text.6337: But chief, the constant few, by death betrayed, Reign, crown'd with myrtle, monarchs of the shadeNot so the wicked;
tgt_text.6338: far they drag their chains, By black lakes sever'd from the blissful plains;
tgt_text.6339: Those should they pass, impassable the gate Where Cerberus howls, grim sentinel of fate.
tgt_text.6340: There snake-hair'd fiends with whips patrol around, Rack'd anguish bellows, and the deeps resound:
tgt_text.6341: There he, who dared to tempt the queen of heaven, Upon an ever-turning wheel is driven :
tgt_text.6342: The Danaids there still strive huge casks to fill, But strive in vain, the casks elude their skill:
tgt_text.6343: There Pelops' sire, to quench his thirsty fires, Still tries the flood, and still the flood retires:
tgt_text.6344: There vultures tear the bow'Is, and drink the gore, Of Tityus, stretch'd enormous on the shore.
tgt_text.6345: Dread love, as vast as endless be their pain
tgt_text.6346: Who tempt my fair, or wish a long campaign.0 let no rival your affections share, Long as this bosom beats, my lovely fair !
tgt_text.6347: Still on you let your prudent nurse attend ;
tgt_text.6348: She'll guard your honour, she's our common friend.
tgt_text.6349: Her tales of love your sorrowings will allay, And, in my absence, make my Delia gay:
tgt_text.6350: Let her o'er all your virgin-train preside, She'll praise th' industrious, and the lazy chide.
tgt_text.6353: Their distaffs drop, they yawn, they nod, they sleep.
tgt_text.6354: Then, if the destinies propitious prove, Then will I rush, all passion, on my love:
tgt_text.6355: My wish'd return no messenger shall tell, I'll seem, my fair, as if from heaven I fell.
tgt_text.6356: A soft confusion flushes all your charms, Your graceful dishabille my bosom warms, You, Delia, fly and clasp me in your arms.
tgt_text.6357: For this surprise, ye powers of love, I pray, Post on, Aurora, bring the rosy day.
tgt_text.6359: How well they lived in Saturn's golden times.
tgt_text.6360: Ere earth lay open to her farthest climes;
tgt_text.6361: Ere hollow pine-trees mounted on the wave, And to the wind their swelling canvass gave;
tgt_text.6362: Or sailors, wand'ring to a world unknown, Prest their deep bark with produce not their own.
tgt_text.6363: No lordly bull then dragg'd the pond rous wain, Nor noble horse obey'd the slavish rein ;
tgt_text.6364: No house was guarded by the jealous wall, No selfish landmark robb'd the wealth of all.
tgt_text.6365: Spontaneous oaks distill'd their honey'd dews, Their milk was offer'd by the teeming ewes :
tgt_text.6366: War had not yet his iron front displayed, Nor savage craft contrived the murd'rous blade.
tgt_text.6367: Danger and death pursue the thunderer's reign, And cross, by countless paths, the land and main.

tgt_text.6371: Yet, if my fated length of life is gone, Be this inscription graved upon my stone, " Here young Tibullus slumbers with the dead, O'er earth and sea by loved Messala led.
tgt_text.6372: "But I, who living yield to gentle love, Dying shall seek the blest Elysian grove.
tgt_text.6373: There tuneful choirs o'er verdant meadows stray, And dance and song delight th' immortal day;
tgt_text.6374: Uncultured cassia scents the teeming ground, And od'rous roses flourish all around.
tgt_text.6375: There many a tender girl and favoured boy Renew the wonted interchange of joy.
tgt_text.6376: There roam the pairs of guiltless lovers dead, With wreaths of myrtle on each youthful head.
tgt_text.6377: But Guilt's pale dens lie hid in night profound, Where sable floods rush horribly around ;
tgt_text.6378: Their snake-crown'd heads the hissing Furies rear, And the damn'd souls are hurried here and there;
tgt_text.6379: His scorpion jaws black Cerberus expands,
tgt_text.6380: And at the brazen gate expecting stands !
tgt_text.6381: There, on the rapid wheel is lust impaled, Lust that the queen of heaven herself assailed.
tgt_text.6382: There Tityus, stretch'd at his enormous length, Feeds the keen vulture with his bleeding strength.
tgt_text.6383: There thirsting Tantalus, with eager eyes
tgt_text.6384: And outstretch’d hands, pursues the stream that flies.
tgt_text.6385: There the false brides who shed their husbands' blood, Through hollow vessels pour the ceaseless flood.
tgt_text.6386: There be the wretch who wishes me to rove, In painful absence from my only love.
tgt_text.6387: But rest for ever pure, my lovely bride, Thy aged nurse still watching at thy side, Telling sweet tales of seasons long gone by-
tgt_text.6388: While, at their lamps, the circling damsels ply
tgt_text.6389: The curious labours of the length’ning thread, Or o'er the distaff bend their drowsy head.
tgt_text.6390: Then, on a sudden, will thy lover come, As if from heaven descending to his home:
tgt_text.6391: No courier's speed my Delia shall prepare, But in her chance undress I'll find the fair.
tgt_text.6392: Then will she run these smiling eyes to meet, Loose her dark locks, and bare her snowy feet.
tgt_text.6394: with what joy I'll strain her to my breast, While tears and tender murmurs speak the rest.

tgt_text.6398: Naked thou stand'st, expos'd to wintry snows !
tgt_text.6399: Naked thou stand'st when burning Sirius glows!

tgt_text.6404: In time soft rains through marble sap their way, And time taught man to tame fierce beasts of prey.

tgt_text.6407: Banish then scruples, if you'd gain a heart;

tgt_text.6409: Oaths bind not eager love, thank heaven's good sire!
tgt_text.6415: Now forests bloom, and purple earth looks gay;
tgt_text.6416: Bleak winter blows, and all her charms decay:
tgt_text.6417: How soon the steed to age's stiffness yields, So late a victor in th' Olympic fields ?
tgt_text.6418: I've seen the aged oft lament their fate, That senseless they had learnt to live too late.
tgt_text.6419: Ye partial gods, and can the snake renew
tgt_text.6420: His youthful vigour and his burnish'd hue ?
tgt_text.6421: But youth and beauty past, is art in vain
tgt_text.6422: To bring the coy deserters back again ?
tgt_text.6423: Jove gives alone the powers of wit and wine, In youth immortal, spite of years, to shine.
tgt_text.6424: Yield prompt compliance to the maid's desires ;
tgt_text.6425: A prompt compliance fans the lover's fires :
tgt_text.6426: Go pleased where'er she goes, though long the way, Though the fierce dog-star dart his sultry ray;
tgt_text.6427: Though painted Iris gird the bluish sky, And sure portends that rattling storms are nigh:
tgt_text.6428: Or, if the fair one pant for sylvan fame, Gay drag the meshes and provoke the game:
tgt_text.6429: Nay, should she choose to risk the driving gale, Or steer, or row, or agile hand the sail:
tgt_text.6430: No toil, though weak, though fearful, thou forbear;
tgt_text.6431: No toils should tire you, and no dangers scare.
tgt_text.6432: Occasion smiles, then snatch an ardent kiss;
tgt_text.6433: The coy may struggle, but will grant the bliss:
tgt_text.6434: The bliss obtain'd, the fictious struggle past, Unbid, they’ll clasp you in their arms at last.
tgt_text.6436: in such degenerate days as these, No more love's gentle wiles the beauteous please I If poor, all gentle stratagems are vain !
tgt_text.6437: The fair ones languish now alone for gain!
tgt_text.6438: Oh may dishonour be the wretch's share, Who first with hateful gold seduced the fair !
tgt_text.6439: Ye charming dames, prefer the tuneful choir, Nor meanly barter heavenly charms for hire.
tgt_text.6441: The purple locks that glow’d On Nisus' head, harmonious song bestow'd !
tgt_text.6443: By tuneful strains alone Fair iv'ry, Pelops, on thy shoulder shone !
tgt_text.6444: While stars with nightly radiance gild the pole, Earth boasts her oaks, or mighty waters roll, The fair, whose beauty poets deign to praise, Shall bloom uninjur'd in poetic lays:
tgt_text.6445: While she who hears not when the Muses call, But flies their fav'rites, gold's inglorious thrall!
tgt_text.6446: Shall prove, believe the bard, or soon, or late, A dread example of avenging fate !
tgt_text.6447: Soft, flattering songs, the Cyprian queen approves:
tgt_text.6448: And aids the suppliant swain with all her loves.

tgt_text.6450: But caution bids you fly th' insidious fair, And paints the perils of their eyes and air;
tgt_text.6451: Nor these alone devoted man subdue, Devoted man their slightest actions woo.
tgt_text.6452: Be cautious those who list-but ye who know Desire's hot fever, and contempt's chill woe, Me grateful praise-contempt shall pain no more;
tgt_text.6453: But wish meet wish, instructed by my lore:
tgt_text.6454: By various means, while others seek for fame, Scorn'd love to counsel be my noblest aim.
tgt_text.6455: Wide stands my gate for all—I rapt foresee
tgt_text.6456: The time, when I Love's oracle shall be !
tgt_text.6457: When round my seat shall press th' enamoured throng Attend my motions, and applaud my song.

tgt_text.6461: Yet spare me, charmer, your disdain betrays
tgt_text.6462: To witty laughter my too boastful lays.
tgt_text.6463: GRAINGER.OF late I boasted I could happy be, Resume the man, and not my Delia see!
tgt_text.6464: My boasts of manhood, boasts of bliss are vain;
tgt_text.6465: Back to my bondage I return again !
tgt_text.6466: And like a top am whirl'd, which boys, for sport.
tgt_text.6467: Lash on the pavement of a level court!
tgt_text.6468: What can atone, my fair, for crimes like these ?
tgt_text.6469: I'll bear with patience, use me as you please!
tgt_text.6470: Yet, by Love's shafts, and by your braided hair, By all the joys we stole, your suppliant spare.
tgt_text.6471: When sickness dimm'd of late your radiant eyes, My restless, fond petitions won the skies.
tgt_text.6472: Thrice I with sulphur purified you round, And thrice the rite, with songs, th' enchantress bound:
tgt_text.6473: The cake, by me thrice sprinkled, put to flight
tgt_text.6474: The death-denouncing phantoms of the night:
tgt_text.6475: And I nine times, in linen garbs array'd, In silent night, nine times to Trivia pray^d.
tgt_text.6478: You love another, your preserver fly !
tgt_text.6479: lie tastes the sweet effects of all my cares, My fond lustrations, and my solemn prayers.
tgt_text.6480: Are these the joys my madding fancy drew, If young-eyed health restored your rosy hue ?
tgt_text.6481: I fondly thought, sweet maid, oh thought in vain !
tgt_text.6482: With you to live a blithesome village swain.
tgt_text.6483: When yellow Ceres asks the reaper's hand, Delia (said I) will guard the reaper's band;
tgt_text.6484: Delia will keep, when hinds unload the vine, The choicest grapes for me, the richest wine:
tgt_text.6485: My flocks she'll count, and oft will sweetly deign
tgt_text.6486: To clasp some prattler of my menial train :
tgt_text.6487: With pious care will load each rural shrine, For ripen'd crops a golden sheaf assign, Gates for my fold, rich clusters for my vine:
tgt_text.6488: No, no domestic care shall touch my soul;
tgt_text.6489: You, Delia, reign despotic o'er the whole ;
tgt_text.6490: And will Messala fly from pomp of state, And deign to enter at my lowly gate ?
tgt_text.6491: The choicest fruitage that my trees afford Delia will cull herself to deck the board;
tgt_text.6492: And wondering, such transcendent worth to see, The fruit present, thy blushing hand-maid she.
tgt_text.6493: Such were the fond chimeras of my brain, Which now the winds have wafted o'er the main.
tgt_text.6494: 0 power of Love, whom still my soul obey'd,
tgt_text.6495: What has my tongue against thy mother said?
tgt_text.6496: Guiltless of ill, unmark'd with incest's stain, I stole no garland from her holy fine:
tgt_text.6497: For crimes like these I'd abject crawl the ground, Kiss her dread threshold, and my forehead wound.
tgt_text.6498: But ye who, falsely wise, deride my pains, Beware;
tgt_text.6500: I've known the young, who ridiculed his rage, Love's humblest vassals when oppress'd with age:
tgt_text.6501: Each art I've known them try to win the fair, Smooth their hoarse voice, and dress their scanty hair:
tgt_text.6502: I've known them, in the street, her maid detain;
tgt_text.6503: And weeping, beg her to assist their pain.
tgt_text.6504: At such preposterous love each school-boy sneers ;
tgt_text.6507: Why do you crush your slave, fair queen of joy ?
tgt_text.6508: Destroying me, your harvest you destroy!
tgt_text.6509: GRAINGER.WITH wine I strove to soothe my love-sick soul, But vengeful Cupid dash'd with tears the bowl:
tgt_text.6510: All mad with rage, to kinder nymphs I flew;
tgt_text.6511: But vigour fled me, when I thought on you.
tgt_text.6512: Balk'd of the rapture, from my arms they run, Swear I'm devoted, and my converse shun !
tgt_text.6513: By what dire witchcraft am I thus betray'd ?
tgt_text.6514: Your face and hair unnerve me, matchless maid:
tgt_text.6515: Not more celestial look'd the sea-born fair, Received by Peleus from her pearly chair.
tgt_text.6516: A rich admirer his addresses paid, And bribed my mistress by a beldam's aid.
tgt_text.6517: From you my ruin, curst procuress, rose ;
tgt_text.6518: What imprecations shall avenge my woes ?
tgt_text.6519: May heaven, in pity to my sufferings, shed Its keenest mischief on your plotting head!
tgt_text.6520: The ghosts of those you robb'd of love's delight, In horrid visions haunt your irksome night!
tgt_text.6521: And, on the chimney, may the boding owl Your rest disturb, and terrify your soul!
tgt_text.6522: By famine stung, to churchyards may you run ;
tgt_text.6523: There feast on offals hungry wolves would shun!
tgt_text.6524: Or howling frantic, in a tatter'd gown, Fierce mastiffs bait you through each crowded town !
tgt_text.6526: a lover's curse the gods approve ;
tgt_text.6527: But keenest vengeance fires the queen of love.
tgt_text.6528: Leave then, my fair, the crafty;
tgt_text.6530: What passion yields not, when such foes invade ?
tgt_text.6531: Your hearts, ye fair, does modest merit claim ?
tgt_text.6532: Though small his fortunes, feed his gentle name;
tgt_text.6533: For genuine love's soft raptures would ye know ?
tgt_text.6534: These raptures merit can alone bestow ;
tgt_text.6535: The sons of opulence are folly's care, But want's rough child is sense and honour's heir.
tgt_text.6536: In vain we sing-the gate still bolted stands;
tgt_text.6537: Come, vengeance, let us burst its sullen bands.
